title: How to Care For the Most Delicate Fabrics

steps.headline: Read the care label  on the fabrics.
steps.description: Before you wash your delicate fabrics in a washing machine, you need to check the tag to see if there are any special procedures you need to follow to clean them. If your fabrics don’t have a label with washing instructions or if it says dry clean only, handwash them to be safe. Never machine-wash extra fine silk, suede, leather, feathers, or fur as they can only be cleaned by a professional dry cleaner.

steps.headline: Check the fabrics for any loose seams or stitches.
steps.description:
Many delicate fabrics have trimming and intricately sewn seams and threads. Before you wash yours in a machine, check to make sure the trims and seams are sewn tight to the garment so they’re unlikely to get caught or come loose in the wash.
Be sure to examine the stitching on sequins which can get tangled up if they’re loose. Use a needle and thread to restitch any loose seams. Handwash your delicate fabrics if you’re unsure about the condition of loose threads or seams.

steps.headline: Organize your delicate fabrics by type and color.
steps.description: Wash like items with like items to avoid damaging the fabric. Separate your delicate fabrics by type to prevent 2 materials from binding to or tangling with another type of fabric. Wash like colors together to prevent staining your fabrics. For example, wool and lace can stick to each other in the wash. Consider the weight of the fabric as well. For instance, you wouldn’t want to machine-wash a sweater with something like a lace shawl or it could possibly stretch or tear it. Never wash white fabrics with color fabrics or they could be stained.

steps.headline: Pretreat stains with a delicate treatment.
steps.description: If your fabric has a stubborn stain on it, pretreat it with a stain remover designed for delicate fabrics before you wash it. Apply the cleaning agent to the stain and allow it to sit for 15 minutes before you wash the fabric. Follow the directions on the packaging of the cleaning agent to make sure it’s safe to use on your fabric.

steps.headline: Place your delicate fabrics in the washing machine.
steps.description: Put your fabrics into the machine before you add your water and detergent. Put any small items into mesh bags to keep them from getting frayed or tangled. Make sure any zippers are zipped and buttons are fastened to keep them from snagging on anything. If you’re handwashing your delicate fabrics, fill a sink or a large bucket with cool water and place your delicates in it.

steps.headline: Add a mild detergent and set the machine to a gentle cycle with cold water.
steps.description: Use liquid detergent to avoid discoloring the fabric and run the washing machine on a short, gentle wash cycle. Use cold water to prevent shrinking or damaging the fabric. To handwash your delicate fabrics, add about 1 teaspoon (4.9 mL) of detergent to your sink or bucket and gently swirl them around for 2 minutes.Tip: If your machine has a presoak option, use it! Soaking the delicate fabric before it goes through a gentle wash cycle will remove all of the dirt from the fabric.

steps.headline: Hang the delicate fabric to dry on a clothesline.
steps.description: Hang the fabrics up to dry immediately after they’re finished washing to prevent wrinkles and creases. For items that are too heavy to hang, like sweaters or large shawls, lie them flat to dry on a clean surface like a table or an ironing board. Use a padded hanger if you don’t have a clothesline. Avoid wire hangers or it could cause your fabrics to lose their shape. Reshape the garment before you lay it flat or it could dry with bulges and wrinkles in the fabric. Do not dry your delicate fabrics in a machine dryer!

steps.headline: Avoid frequent washing of your delicate fabrics.
steps.description: If you wear an item made of delicate fabric, hang it up inside out to let it air out and to allow any perspiration to dry out. Washing the fabric and start to break it down so try to wash it as rarely as possible. Don’t use perfume or cologne on delicate fabrics as the oils can discolor the fabric.

steps.headline: Use a clothes brush to remove dust or dirt from delicate fabrics.
steps.description: A clothes brush is a velvet-faced lint brush that’s safe to use on delicate fabrics. If your fabric collects dirt or hair, a clothes brush is a great option to clean the material in between washes. The soft bristles will lift the dirt and dust and won’t leave any residue behind. You can find clothes brushes at your local department store or online.Tip: Remove dirt and dust immediately after you wear the fabric so they don’t adhere to it.

steps.headline: Hang delicate fabrics on padded hangers.
steps.description: Whenever you hang up your fabrics to store them, use a padded hanger to help prevent the fabric from getting any bulges or creases in it. Plastic or wire hangers can stretch the fabric. Do not hang clean fabrics next to used fabrics. The oils and dirt can transfer from one item to another. Make sure there is space between the fabrics when you hang them. Don’t squish them together.

steps.headline: Fold heavy items like gowns and sweaters.
steps.description: Knitted fabric, gowns, and heavier items like sweaters should not be stored on hangers or the fabric can warp and stretch. Fold them flat and store them on a shelf or in a plastic container. Make sure they aren’t compressed by other clothes or they could develop wrinkles and creases in them.

steps.headline: Keep delicate fabrics away from sunlight.
steps.description: The UV radiation in sunlight can discolor and damage the fabric so don’t hang them up near an open window or outside. Keep them in an area with low light to prevent them from fading. A closet or an area away from a window is ideal.

steps.headline: Store delicate fabric in a cool, well-ventilated place.
steps.description: Good air circulation is important in order to preserve fabric. Make sure the place you store your delicate fabric is not warm or humid or it could break down the material. Never store your delicate fabrics in a basement or attic where temperature and humidity fluctuate. Don’t put your fabrics in plastic or vinyl bags.
